Briefly The Kinks and Steely Dan were right.  Do It Again.  Logic starts out with Small Scale Integration (SSI).  A bunch of NAND gates limited by the number of pins on the package.  As technology improves we go to Medium Scale Integration (MSI).  An 8 bit counter for instance.  Technology improves some more and we go to Large Scale Integration (LSI).  Then VLSI.  Then a totally new technology comes out in SSI.  Then goes to MSI, LSI and VLSI.  ALU's may seem old hat, but with Field Programmable Gate Arrays and other programmable logic, they become core components in a library.  All of sudden every minute detail of this design is important again.  A newer technology will then come along. Do It Again.

based on my own puzzlement, i believe, that it's worth to emphasize/notice at this (4:22) point, that the two carriers are never equal to 1 simultaneously, otherwise we would lose one bit in this case.
this follows from the fact, that the carrier in the half adder is equal to 1 if and only if both its inputs are equal to 1, at which point its sum is equal to 0. and since the sum of the left adder is the a input of the right adder we get our conclusion.

you guys kinda forgot to explain subtraction:
Here is how I think it is done, I'm not sure if this is exactly how we are currently doing it , so someone correct if I made a mistake.

for A-B with A and B both positive numbers:
1) invert B (0 becomes 1 and 1 becomes 0), easily done with Not-gates.
2) add A and inverted B together by the normal addition circuit
EDIT: Then you add 1 to that sum to get the right answer (thanks to MarioFanGamer)
3) the sum is the outcome of A-B, the carry tells the sign: 1 if positive, 0 if negative.

I get that there is only a limited amount of time in a video, and that there is a lot of stuff to explain. But I find the concept of subtracting through addition ingenious and worth some attention. It's not as intuitive as addition with logic gates.

Just a note: In most architectures (x86 included), the overflow bit is for SIGNED overflow. The carry bit is in a flag marked carry or unsigned overflow. This distinction is extremely important and the cause of many subtle bugs for new assembly programmers.

Thus the flags are Z (zero), C (carry), O (Overflow), S (Sign). There are many more (depending on the cpu), but you need these to be able to handle the inequality conditionals correctly for both signed and unsigned integers.

Hey Carrie Ann,
What about 2's complement and negative numbers. That ALU in this video would have some major issues with comparing 2 integers by subtracting them. Just look at MIN_INT(a large negative number) compared to MAX_INT. Subtracting those numbers would lead to the incorrect result due to overflow.

As a side note to those wondering how subtraction is done, it is also done through addition. The way computers store negative integers in binary is a system called 2's complement, which is difficult to discuss in a short text comment, but it allows the addition of a positive integer X and a negative integer Y to equal X - Y. If you want to subtract Y from X you just turn Y into a negative number (which is a very fast operation) and then add them together.
